content: I wonder if the volume on \R is defined to be complete. Leansearch and Mathlib docs didn't help me that much. I hoped something like #eval (@volume _ \R).IsComplete works (which did not). Any help would be very appreciated!

Yes, the volume measure on the real numbers is the Lebesgue measure, which is complete. Btw the correct thing to try when looking for an instance is

import Mathlib

open MeasureTheory

#synth (volume : Measure ℝ).IsComplete
And indeed we don't have the instance! PR welcome :smile:
I don't think that's true because the measurable space structure on R\mathbb{R}R is the Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra, which does not contains all negligable sets.
Yaël Dillies Does 'no instance' mean there is no theorem on the fact? What I essentially need is a NullMeasurable set is Measurable (if it is.)
It seems like the only IsComplete instance is for completion

Etienne Marion said:

I don't think that's true because the measurable space structure on R\mathbb{R}R is the Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra, which does not contains all negligable sets.

Aaah right, volume isn't the Lebesgue measure, but the restriction of the Lebesgue measure to Borel sets
Thanks all, I am happy to have a unified answer now!

Yaël Dillies said:

Etienne Marion said:
Aaah right, volume isn't the Lebesgue measure, but the restriction of the Lebesgue measure to Borel sets

I don't think that is quite true: volume is the Lebesgue measure, and has the correct value on all Lebesgue-measurable sets, even if they are not Borel-measurable. It's just that the (standard) ambient sigma-algebra is the Borel sigma-algebra.

Aah, you're pointing out the following phenomenon:

import Mathlib

open MeasureTheory ENNReal

  -- let α be a set
variable (α : Type)
  -- ... equipped with a σ-algebra
  [MeasurableSpace α]
  -- ... and let μ be a measure on α.
  (μ : Measure α)
  -- Then if s is an arbitrary subset of α
  (s : Set α)
  -- it turns out that μ(s) makes sense!

#check μ s -- ℝ≥0∞
Yes, and docs#MeasureTheory.measure_eq_iInf characterizes what a measure does on all (non-measurable) sets in terms of its behavior on measurable sets.
Jaehyeon Seo has marked this topic as unresolved.

I see, so a volume on a Euclidean space is a Lebesgue measure, and a volume of a non-measurable set is computed using the corresponding outer measure.
A Legesgue measure is always complete, but based on my search, it seems that there is no corresponding theorem in MathLib. I wonder whether this really is the case. Is this related to the comment of @Ruben Van de Velde ?

My understanding is that "a volume on a Euclidean space is a Lebesgue measure" is not really a well-defined statement here. One could argue that the volume "is" Lebesgue measure in the sense that it gives the same answer for any subset of the reals, but one could argue that it also "is not" Lebesgue measure in the sense that the underlying sigma algebras are different. If you'd like to write a formal statement of what you mean it would be much easier to say yes or no to it. #mwe s are always the best way to ask questions in situations like this.
Thinking about it more, I believe what you want is precisely docs#MeasureTheory.NullMeasurableSet.of_null

Jaehyeon Seo said:

I see, so a volume on a Euclidean space is a Lebesgue measure, and a volume of a non-measurable set is computed using the corresponding outer measure.
A Legesgue measure is always complete, but based on my search, it seems that there is no corresponding theorem in MathLib. I wonder whether this really is the case. Is this related to the comment of Ruben Van de Velde ?

The Lebesgue measure is not complete w.r.t. the Borel sets, and so (volume : Measure ℝ).IsComplete is false.
The Lebesgue measure is complete w.r.t. the Lebesgue measurable sets, which is docs#MeasureTheory.Measure.completion.isComplete
NullMeasurableSet (s : Set Real) states that s is Lebesgue measurable.
NullMeasurableSpace Real volume is the Reals, but equipped with the Lebesgue measurable sets as the sigma-algebra.
(volume : Measure Real).completion is the Lebesgue measure viewed as a measure w.r.t. the Lebesgue measurable sets.
It's all there, but stated a little differently than in textbooks.

Now it becomes clear to me. I was mainly confused because I didn't fix the underlying sigma algebra as the Borel sets (docs#Real.measurableSpace) and instead assumed it to be the Lebesgue measurable sets when considering the Lebesgue measure. Thanks, everyone, for pointing this out! :smiling_face_with_hearts:
Jaehyeon Seo has marked this topic as resolved.
